title: Care of Self — Hair Brushing Routine
description: The child learns a complete hair brushing routine: gathering tools, brushing from ends to roots, styling simply, and cleaning the brush. This builds independence in personal grooming and establishes a self-care habit.
instructions:
1. Set up a grooming station: mirror (child height), hairbrush, comb, hair ties or clips, small container.
2. 'Taking care of yourself is important work. Today we learn how to brush your hair properly.'
3. Stand at the mirror. 'First, we start at the ENDS — the bottom of the hair. Gently brush the ends to remove tangles.'
4. 'Then move UP a little bit and brush down. Keep going higher until you're brushing from the top all the way to the ends.'
5. 'If you hit a tangle, hold the hair ABOVE the tangle and brush gently below it. Never yank!'
6. 'Now you can style: a ponytail, a braid attempt, or just leave it down. YOUR choice!'
7. 'Clean the brush: pull out any loose hair and put it in the trash.'
materials_needed: Small basket or tray for grooming tools

slides.heading: Care of Self
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This slide has a special title for our fun activity today! It's all about taking care of ourselves, and we're going to learn how to make our hair super nice.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a grooming station where the child can see themselves in the mirror. Arrange tools in a basket.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special tools we need for our hair adventure! We have a mirror so we can see our beautiful faces, a brush to make our hair smooth, a comb for tricky spots, and some fun clips and ties to make our hair fancy. Ask your grown-up to help you find these so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Taking care of YOUR body is YOUR job. Today we learn how to brush your hair so it looks nice and feels comfortable.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Taking care of your body is so important, and it's your special job! Today, we're going to learn how to brush your hair all by yourself so it looks neat and feels comfy.

slides.text: 'Start at the ENDS — the bottom of your hair. Brush gently. This gets the small tangles out first.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we start way down at the very bottom of your hair, at the ends. Gently brush there to get out any little knots, like we're tickling your hair!

slides.text: 'Move your brush UP a little and brush down again. Keep going higher. End by brushing from the very top to the very bottom in one smooth stroke.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we move the brush up just a little bit and brush down again. We keep going higher and higher until we can brush from the tippy-top all the way down to the ends in one big, smooth swoop!

slides.text: 'If you find a tangle: HOLD the hair above the tangle with one hand. Brush gently below with the other. Never pull hard!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh, if we find a tangle, don't worry! We hold the hair right above the tangle with one hand, and then we use our brush to gently go through the part below it. We never pull hard, we're super gentle!

slides.text: 'Now style your hair if you want: a ponytail, clips, or just leave it down. Look in the mirror — you did that yourself!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, now you can make your hair look super cool! You can put it in a ponytail, try a braid, or just let it be free. Look in the mirror, you look amazing because YOU did that!

slides.prompt: Practice the full routine: brush ends first, work your way up, handle any tangles gently, and choose a style. Then clean the brush by removing loose hair.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice everything we learned together! We'll start at the ends, brush our way up, be gentle with any tangles, and pick a fun style for your hair. Then, we'll pull out all the little hairs from our brush to keep it clean.

slides.text: 'You can brush your own hair now! Do this every morning as part of getting ready. Put your tools back in the basket when you're done.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child brush their hair from ends to top without assistance and clean the brush afterward?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a hair brushing superstar! You can totally brush your own hair now, just like a big kid! Try to do it every morning to get ready for a fun day, and remember to put all your tools back in their basket when you're all done.

parent_notes: Self-care is a core Montessori practical life area. Maria Montessori observed that children who can dress, groom, and care for themselves develop profound self-confidence. The technique of brushing from ends to roots prevents painful pulling and is the method hairdressers use. Setting up a permanent grooming station at the child's height sends the message: 'This is YOUR responsibility and YOUR space.' Be patient as the child learns — it takes practice to brush the back of one's own head. The goal is independence: mornings become smoother when the child can handle their own grooming. If hair is very short, adapt to combing and focus on the routine aspect.

title: Digraph Review — Reading Words with sh, ch, th, wh
description: A comprehensive review of digraphs learned in previous quarters. The child reads words with sh, ch, th, and wh, distinguishing digraphs from blends, and practices these patterns in connected text.
instructions:
1. 'Let's review our digraphs! A digraph is two letters that make ONE new sound. Remember the difference from blends?'
2. SH: ship, shop, shell, wish, fish, brush, cash. 'sh makes one sound: /sh/.'
3. CH: chip, chop, chest, much, lunch, rich, catch. '/ch/ — one new sound!'
4. TH: this, that, the, with, math, bath, then, thick. 'th can be soft (the) or hard (thick).'
5. WH: when, what, where, while, white, wheel, whisper.
6. Mixed reading: present words with digraphs, blends, and silent e mixed together.
7. 'Read each word and tell me: is it a digraph, blend, or magic e word?'
8. Read sentences containing all patterns.
materials_needed: Sorting categories: digraph, blend, magic e

slides.heading: Digraph Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big title! It says "Digraph Review," and we're going to look at special letter friends: sh, ch, th, and wh. These letters like to hold hands and make a brand new sound, just for them!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word cards with digraph, blend, and magic e words mixed together. Set up three sorting labels.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some fun things to play with today! We have word cards with letters on them, some special signs to put things into groups, and a mat to put everything on. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get these ready for our game!

slides.text: 'You know so many phonics patterns now! Today we're reviewing DIGRAPHS. Remember: a digraph is two letters that make ONE brand new sound.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to be super readers today! Remember how some letters like to work together? Well, we're learning about special pairs of letters called digraphs. They hold hands so tightly that they make just one new sound!

slides.text: 'SH: /sh/. What words start with sh? Ship, shell, shop. What words END with sh? Fish, wish, brush!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's listen to the "sh" sound, like when you tell someone to be quiet! We can find "sh" at the beginning of words like "ship" and "shell," and sometimes at the end of words like "fish" and "wish."

slides.text: 'CH: /ch/. Chip, chest, church. TH: /th/. This, that, math, bath. WH: /wh/. When, what, where, white.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we have more special sounds! "Ch" sounds like when you chew your yummy food. "Th" can be soft like in "the" or a bit stronger like in "thick." And "wh" is like when you ask a question, like "what" or "when"!

slides.text: 'Now the challenge: digraphs make ONE sound, but blends make TWO sounds you can hear separately. SH is a digraph. BL is a blend. Can you tell the difference?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is a little tricky, but I know you can do it! Digraphs are like best friends who make one sound, but blends are like two friends who still make their own sounds. We need to listen carefully to tell them apart, like "sh" for one sound and "bl" for two sounds.

slides.prompt: Sort these word cards into three groups: DIGRAPH words, BLEND words, and MAGIC E words. Read each word first, then decide which group it belongs to.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for a sorting game! We'll look at each word card, say the word, and decide if it's a digraph word, a blend word, or a magic "e" word. Let's put each card in the right spot on our mat.

slides.text: 'You can tell digraphs, blends, and magic e words apart! Your phonics toolkit is getting really powerful.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read words with all four digraphs and correctly sort mixed-pattern words into categories?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You are so good at finding digraphs, blends, and magic "e" words. You listened so well and learned all about these special letter sounds! Your reading superpowers are growing!

parent_notes: This review lesson consolidates the child's phonics knowledge by requiring them to identify and categorize different patterns. The distinction between digraphs (two letters, one sound: sh, ch, th, wh) and blends (two letters, two sounds: bl, cr, gr) is important and can be confusing. A simple test: 'Can you hear BOTH letters?' If yes, it's a blend. If the two letters make a completely new sound, it's a digraph. The sorting activity makes this concrete. By now, the child has an impressive toolkit: short vowels, long vowels (magic e), digraphs, and blends. This covers the vast majority of English words they'll encounter in early reading. Celebrate how far they've come!

title: Bead Chain — Chain of 6 (Skip Counting)
description: The child uses the short bead chain of 6 to count by sixes. This longer chain provides practice with a more challenging skip counting sequence and connects to multiplication by 6.
instructions:
1. Bring out the short chain of 6. 'The chain of 6! Each bar has 6 beads.'
2. Lay the chain in a straight line. This chain has 36 bars (6 x 6 x 6 = 216 for the long chain, but the short chain goes to 6 x 6 = 36).
3. Count by 6s together: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36.
4. Place number arrows at each bar.
5. 'Look at 36 — that's 6 x 6. The square of 6! We built this with bead bars last week.'
6. 'Notice: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36. These are all EVEN numbers!'
7. Child places arrows independently and practices the sequence.
8. Count forward and backward.

slides.heading: Bead Chain Counting
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It tells us we're going to play a game with a special bead chain and learn how to count in a new way, called "skip counting" by sixes!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the mat. The short chain of 6 has 6 bars, going up to 36.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some cool things to play with today! We have a long string of beads called a bead chain, and some special number cards. We also have a big mat to put everything on, so let's get it all ready on the mat!

slides.text: 'Today we have the chain of 6! Six beads in each bar. Let's stretch it out and count!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's our special bead chain! See how each little group of beads has six? We're going to stretch it out nice and long so we can count all the way to the end together.

slides.text: 'Count by 6s with me. Touch each bar: 6... 12... 18... 24... 30... 36!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's count together by sixes! We touch each group of six beads and say the next number: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36! It's like taking big jumps!

slides.text: 'Place the arrows: 6 at the first bar, 12 at the second, all the way to 36. Remember — 36 is 6 squared!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to put the number cards on the bead chain! We put the card with '6' after the first group, '12' after the second, and so on, until we put '36' at the very end. That 36 is special, it's like 6 groups of 6!

slides.text: 'Look at our numbers: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36. They're all EVEN numbers. And look at the ones digit: 6, 2, 8, 4, 0, 6 — it repeats!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at the numbers we counted: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36. Do you see a pattern? They all end in a number that's easy to share, and the last number in each number is like a little dance: 6, 2, 8, 4, 0, 6!

slides.prompt: Remove the arrows and place them back yourself. Practice saying: 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36. Try it without looking! Then count backward.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the teacher! Take the number cards off and put them back in the right spots all by yourself. Try to say the numbers as you put them on, and then try saying them backward too! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Six times six is 36 — the square of 6! You're counting by larger numbers now. This is multiplication in action!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count by 6s to 36 and place arrows correctly on the chain?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job counting by sixes all the way to 36! You learned that 6 times 6 is 36, and you're practicing counting by bigger numbers, which is super smart!

parent_notes: The chain of 6 introduces a more challenging skip counting sequence. Six is harder than 2, 3, or 5 because the numbers don't follow as obvious a pattern. However, the physical chain makes it manageable — the child counts beads, not abstract numbers. Point out that all multiples of 6 are even (because 6 is even). The ones digit pattern (6, 2, 8, 4, 0, 6, 2, 8...) is interesting and can help with memorization. Don't require memorization — fluency develops through repeated physical counting. The connection between the chain of 6 and the bead bar square (6 x 6 = 36 from last week) helps the child see that skip counting and squaring are related.

title: Oceans of the World
description: The child learns the names and locations of the five oceans: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Arctic, and Southern. Using the globe, they discover that oceans cover most of Earth's surface and connect all the continents.
instructions:
1. Hold the globe. 'Look at the blue parts. What is all that blue? WATER! Oceans!'
2. 'More than 70% of Earth is covered in water. That means if you could cut Earth into 10 pieces, 7 would be ocean!'
3. Point to each ocean: 'This is the PACIFIC — the biggest ocean. It's SO big that all the land on Earth could fit inside it!'
4. 'The ATLANTIC is between the Americas and Europe/Africa. The INDIAN ocean is near India (that's how it got its name!).'
5. 'The ARCTIC ocean is at the top — it's covered in ice! The SOUTHERN ocean is at the bottom, around Antarctica.'
6. Three-period lesson for the ocean names.
7. Child labels oceans on a blank world map.

slides.heading: Oceans of the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going on an adventure to learn all about the big, blue oceans that cover our whole Earth! There are five special oceans we'll discover.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe and a blank world map ready. The child will label the oceans on the blank map.
slides.mascot_explanation: To play our ocean game, we need a few things! We have a big round ball that looks like Earth, called a globe, and a paper with just the land, called a map. We'll also use a blue crayon to color and a pencil to write. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these for our fun!

slides.text: 'Look at our globe. What color covers MOST of it? BLUE! That's water — the OCEANS. Earth should really be called Ocean!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at our globe! See all that beautiful blue? That's water, and we call those big blue parts the OCEANS! Our Earth has so much water, it's like a giant swimming pool!

slides.text: 'There are FIVE oceans. The biggest is the PACIFIC. It's between Asia and the Americas. It covers more area than ALL the land on Earth!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's meet the biggest ocean of all, the PACIFIC! It's so super-duper big that all the land in the whole world could fit inside it. Can you imagine how much water that is?

slides.text: 'The ATLANTIC is between the Americas on one side and Europe and Africa on the other. Many explorers sailed across the Atlantic!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up is the ATLANTIC Ocean. It's like a big blue path between the places where we live and other lands across the sea. People sailed on this ocean to visit new places a long, long time ago!

slides.text: 'The INDIAN Ocean is near India. The ARCTIC Ocean is at the North Pole — it's frozen! And the SOUTHERN Ocean circles Antarctica at the South Pole.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We have three more oceans to learn about! The INDIAN Ocean is close to a place called India. The ARCTIC Ocean is way up at the tippy-top of the Earth and it's covered in ice! And the SOUTHERN Ocean is all the way at the bottom, where it's very cold.

slides.prompt: Color the oceans blue on your blank world map. Label each one: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Arctic, Southern. Can you name them from biggest to smallest?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be an ocean explorer! We're going to color all the oceans blue on your paper map, and then we'll write their names. It's like making your very own ocean picture!

slides.text: 'Five oceans cover most of our planet. They connect all the continents and are home to millions of creatures!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all 5 oceans and point to their approximate locations on the globe?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned about all five amazing oceans that cover our big Earth. They are home to so many cool fish and sea creatures, and they connect all the lands together. You are such a great ocean expert now!

parent_notes: Children are usually amazed to learn that oceans cover more than 70% of Earth. This fact helps them understand why Earth looks blue from space. The Montessori globe is ideal for this lesson because it shows the continuous nature of ocean water — it's really one big ocean divided into named sections. Start with the Pacific (largest) and work through to the Arctic and Southern (smallest). Mnemonics can help: 'Please Always Include Arctic Somewhere' (Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Arctic, Southern). You can extend this by discussing ocean animals, ocean currents, or why the ocean is salty. This lesson connects to earlier land/water form work and continent studies.

title: Read-Aloud: Tacky the Penguin by Helen Lester
description: Reading 'Tacky the Penguin' by Helen Lester, a humorous story about an odd penguin whose unusual behavior saves his companions from hunters.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Tacky. Does he look like the other penguins?'
2. Read aloud with humor — Tacky's loud voice, cannonball dives, and Hawaiian shirts.
3. Compare Tacky to his companions: 'How is Tacky different?'
4. When the hunters come, ask: 'What happened? Did Tacky's differences help?'
5. Discuss: 'Is it good to be different? Why?'
6. Celebrate uniqueness: everyone has something special to offer.
materials_needed: Tacky the Penguin by Helen Lester
Optional: stuffed penguin or penguin pictures

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Tacky the Penguin by Helen Lester
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to read a fun story called "Tacky the Penguin." It's going to be a super silly adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready in a cozy spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the special book we need for our story today! We'll snuggle up and read all about Tacky.

slides.text: Cover: 'Meet Tacky! He's an odd bird. What do you notice about him compared to the other penguins?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this picture! This is Tacky the penguin. Do you see how he looks a little different from the other penguins? Let's see what makes him special!

slides.text: Read with lots of expression — Tacky is loud, enthusiastic, and wonderfully different. Ham it up!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, because we're going to read this story with big voices and lots of fun sounds! It's going to be so exciting!

slides.text: Discuss: 'How was Tacky different? What did the hunters think? Did being different turn out to be a good thing?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We'll talk about how Tacky was different and if that was a good thing. Did his differences help his friends? Let's find out together!

slides.prompt: What makes YOU special or different? Draw a picture of yourself doing something only you do. Share it proudly, like Tacky!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be special! Can you draw a picture of something that makes YOU unique and wonderful? I can't wait to see your amazing drawing!

slides.text: 'Tacky was an odd bird, but a very nice bird to have around! Being different can be our superpower.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how Tacky's differences helped save the day?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we finished the story! Tacky showed us that being different is super cool and can even be a superpower. You are special too!

parent_notes: This story celebrates individuality and being yourself. Helen Lester's humor makes it accessible while the deeper message about valuing diversity is powerful. It connects to Montessori's respect for each child's unique development. Children who feel 'different' find this story especially affirming.

title: Baric Tablets — Weight Discrimination
description: The child works with Montessori baric tablets, comparing the weight of tablets made from different woods. With eyes closed, they sort tablets into light, medium, and heavy groups, refining the baric (weight) sense.
instructions:
1. Present the three sets of baric tablets: light (balsa or light wood), medium, and heavy (mahogany or dark wood).
2. 'These tablets look similar in size, but they feel DIFFERENT. Let's find out how!'
3. Pick up a light tablet and a heavy tablet, one in each hand. 'Which is heavier? Which is lighter?'
4. Introduce the medium weight. Three-period lesson: heavy, medium, light.
5. Mix all tablets together. Child sorts by weight with eyes open first.
6. 'Now let's try with eyes CLOSED!' Blindfold optional.
7. Child sorts all tablets into three weight groups by feel alone.
8. Check by looking at the wood color/type.
materials_needed: Montessori baric tablets (3 sets of different weights)

slides.heading: Baric Tablets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to play a game today to help our hands feel how heavy or light things are. It's like a special superpower for your hands!

slides.setup_instructions: Place all three sets on the mat. If you don't have baric tablets, create them from different materials: cardboard (light), wood (medium), stone tiles (heavy) cut to the same size.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these flat pieces! These are our special "baric tablets," and they are all the same size, but they feel different in our hands. We also have a soft mat to put them on, and a sleepy mask to wear later if we want!

slides.text: 'Today we're training our hands to feel WEIGHT — how heavy things are. These tablets are the same size, but they have different weights!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to use our hands to discover how heavy or light things feel. Even though these look the same, they have secret weights inside!

slides.text: 'Pick up this one in your left hand and this one in your right. Which is HEAVIER? Which is LIGHTER?' Let the child feel the difference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's hold one tablet in this hand and one in the other. Feel that? One feels a little heavier, and the other feels lighter, right? It's like holding a feather versus a little rock!

slides.text: 'Now here's a MEDIUM one — not heavy, not light, but in between. Can you feel the difference?'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this new tablet? It's not super heavy and not super light, it's just right in the middle! Can you feel how it's different from the other two we just held?

slides.text: 'I'm going to mix them all up. Sort them into three groups: HEAVY, MEDIUM, and LIGHT.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh, I'm going to mix all the tablets up! Now, we need to be super detectives and put them into three piles: the heaviest ones, the lightest ones, and the ones that are in the middle.

slides.prompt: Close your eyes (or use the blindfold). I'll hand you tablets one at a time. Sort them into heavy, medium, and light groups using ONLY your sense of weight!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We'll close our eyes, or put on our sleepy mask, and I'll give you tablets one by one. You have to use your super hand senses to guess if it's heavy, medium, or light all by yourself!

slides.text: 'Your hands can sense tiny differences in weight! This sense is called the BARIC sense. Cooks use it when they hold ingredients. Scientists use it in labs!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort at least 6 tablets into correct weight categories with eyes closed?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job feeling all the different weights! Your hands learned to be super strong at sensing heavy and light things, just like a chef knows how much flour to use. That special hand sensing power is called the baric sense!

parent_notes: The baric tablets isolate the sense of weight (the baric sense). By closing their eyes, the child eliminates visual cues and must rely entirely on their hands' ability to detect weight differences. This is challenging and requires concentration. The three-period lesson (This is heavy. This is medium. This is light. Show me heavy. What is this?) builds vocabulary for weight description. If you don't have Montessori baric tablets, you can create alternatives: identical containers filled with different amounts of sand, identical-sized blocks of different materials (foam, wood, stone), or sealed bags with different contents. The key is that the objects look similar but differ in weight.

title: Reading Fluency — Simple Chapter Book Introduction
description: The child reads a simple early reader chapter book, transitioning from picture books to longer texts with chapters. This milestone builds reading stamina, comprehension across pages, and the excitement of a continued story.
instructions:
1. Choose an appropriate early chapter book (Frog and Toad, Henry and Mudge, or similar level).
2. 'Today you're going to read a CHAPTER BOOK! That's a book with chapters — like sections of the story.'
3. 'We'll read one chapter together today. It's like one little adventure within a bigger story.'
4. Child reads aloud. Help with difficult words using phonics strategies: 'Sound it out. Do you see a pattern you know?'
5. After the chapter: 'What happened? Who are the characters? What do you think will happen next?'
6. 'You don't have to finish the whole book today. That's the exciting part of chapter books — you come back tomorrow to find out what happens!'
7. Mark the place with a bookmark.
materials_needed: Early chapter book (Frog and Toad, Henry and Mudge, Owl at Home, or similar)

slides.heading: Reading Fluency
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to read a *chapter book* today! It's like a super special book that has different parts to the story.

slides.setup_instructions: Choose a book appropriate for the child's level. Frog and Toad are good because chapters are short (4-5 pages) and self-contained.
slides.mascot_explanation: To read our chapter book, we need a few things! We need the chapter book itself, a special marker called a bookmark, and a cozy spot to sit. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things?

slides.text: 'You've been reading picture books and short stories. Today you're ready for something bigger: a CHAPTER BOOK!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how we've read lots of fun books with big pictures? Well, today we're going to try a *chapter book*! It's a little bit bigger and has more story inside.

slides.text: 'A chapter book has sections called chapters. Each chapter is like a little story. Today we'll read Chapter 1!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This chapter book has special parts called chapters. Think of each chapter like one little adventure in a bigger story. Today, we get to read the very first chapter!

slides.text: 'Read aloud to me. Take your time. If you get stuck on a word, try sounding it out. Use everything you know: short vowels, magic e, digraphs, blends.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the reader! Read the words out loud to me. If you see a tricky word, try sounding it out like we practiced. You can do it!

slides.text: After reading: 'Great job! Tell me what happened in this chapter. Who are the main characters? What was the problem?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After you read, I'll ask you some fun questions about the story. We'll talk about who was in the story and what happened. It's like being a story detective!

slides.prompt: Read Chapter 1 (or the first story) aloud. When you're done, tell me: Who? What happened? How did it end? Place a bookmark where you stopped.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's read this first chapter together! When we finish, tell me all about it – who was there and what happened. Then, we'll put our bookmark in so we know where to stop.

slides.text: 'You read your first chapter! And the story continues tomorrow. That's what's exciting about chapter books — there's always more!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read the chapter with reasonable fluency and answer basic comprehension questions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You read your first chapter of a chapter book! The best part is, we get to come back tomorrow to find out what happens next in the story. How exciting is that?!

parent_notes: The transition to chapter books is a major reading milestone. Choose a book where each chapter is short (3-6 pages) and somewhat self-contained — 'Frog and Toad' by Arnold Lobel is ideal because each chapter is a complete mini-story. 'Henry and Mudge' by Cynthia Rylant and 'Owl at Home' by Arnold Lobel are also excellent choices. The child may need support — alternate reading (you read a page, they read a page) is perfectly appropriate at this stage. The most important thing is comprehension: 'What happened? Why? What might happen next?' The experience of putting in a bookmark and returning later teaches that reading is an ongoing journey, not a single-sitting activity.

title: Bead Chain — Chain of 7 (Skip Counting)
description: The child uses the short bead chain of 7 to count by sevens. The sequence 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49 builds familiarity with multiples of 7, connecting to days of the week.
instructions:
1. Bring out the short chain of 7. 'The chain of 7! Seven is a special number — how many days in a week?'
2. Lay the chain in a straight line.
3. Count by 7s together: 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49.
4. Place number arrows at each bar.
5. '49 is the square of 7: 7 x 7 = 49!'
6. 'Notice something? 7 — one week. 14 — two weeks. 21 — three weeks. 28 — four weeks, almost a month!'
7. Child practices placing arrows and reciting the sequence.
8. 'Counting by 7s is harder than 2s or 5s, but the beads help us!'

slides.heading: Bead Chain Counting
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to play a counting game with special beads. We're going to learn how to count in a super cool way by sevens!

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the mat. Have a calendar nearby to show the connection between 7s and weeks.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our counting adventure! We have a special bead chain, these little number cards, and a big soft mat to put them on. Maybe we can even use a calendar to help us count! Ask your grown-up to help you find everything.

slides.text: 'Seven is a SPECIAL number. How many days in a week? SEVEN! Today we count by 7s with the chain of 7.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Seven is a really special number! Do you know how many days are in one whole week? It's seven! Today, we're going to use our bead chain to count by sevens, just like counting the days in weeks.
Let's count together, nice and slow! We'll say the numbers as we touch each bead group: 7... 14... 21... 28... 35... 42... 49! That's seven groups of seven beads!

slides.text: Place the arrows. 'Each number is one more week! 7 = one week. 14 = two weeks. 21 = three weeks. 28 = four weeks!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to put these number cards next to our beads. Each number shows how many weeks have gone by. So, 7 beads means one week, 14 beads means two weeks, and so on!

slides.text: '49 is 7 x 7 — the SQUARE of 7. That's 7 weeks of days!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This last number, 49, is super special! It means we counted seven groups of seven beads, and that's how many days are in seven whole weeks! It's like counting a whole lot of days all at once!

slides.prompt: Place all the arrows. Practice counting: 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49. Look at the calendar — can you count 7 days and land on the same day of the week?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the expert counter! Let's put all the number cards in the right spots and count all the way to 49 by sevens. We can even look at the calendar to see how many days are in a week. You can do it!

slides.text: '7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42, 49! You can count by 7s. Every time you count 7 days, a whole week has passed!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count by 7s to 49 and connect the sequence to weeks on a calendar?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You counted all the way to 49 by sevens! Every time we count to seven, a whole week has passed, just like magic! You're such a super math star!

parent_notes: Seven is one of the harder skip counting numbers, but the connection to the calendar makes it meaningful. Show the child on a calendar: starting from any day, count 7 days forward and you land on the same day of the week. This is counting by 7s in real life! 14 is two weeks, 21 is three weeks, 28 is four weeks (roughly a month). This practical connection helps the sequence feel less abstract. The bead chain provides the concrete support needed — the child touches and counts real beads. Don't expect memorization yet; familiarity and understanding come from repeated physical counting. The square of 7 (49) is a big number, and the child should feel proud of counting this high.

title: Plant Growth Observation — Seedling Documentation
description: The child observes their growing seedlings (planted in week 19), measures growth, and documents changes. This lesson develops scientific observation skills and connects to the ongoing gardening project.
instructions:
1. Bring the seedling pots to the work area.
2. 'Let's be scientists today! We're going to OBSERVE and MEASURE our plants.'
3. 'First, look carefully. What has changed since last time? Describe what you see.'
4. If sprouts have appeared: 'Look! The seed has germinated! That means it started growing.'
5. Measure the height of any sprouts with a ruler. Record in the garden journal.
6. 'What color are the leaves? Are there one or two leaves? How tall is the stem?'
7. Draw the plant in the journal with accurate detail.
8. 'What does the plant need now? More sun? Water? Space?'
9. Compare to the first journal entry: 'Look how much has changed!'

slides.heading: Plant Observation
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we get to be super scientists today and watch our little plants grow. We're going to see how much they've changed!

slides.setup_instructions: Bring the seedlings to a well-lit work area. Have the garden journal open to the next blank page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our plant adventure! We have our baby plants in their pots, a special stick to measure how tall they get, a notebook to draw in, and even a magnifying glass to see tiny details. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get all these ready!

slides.text: 'Our seeds have been growing! Today we're going to observe them like real scientists — carefully, precisely, and with good records.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be super scientists! We've been waiting for our seeds to grow, and now we get to look at them very, very closely. We'll see what amazing things have happened underground and above!

slides.text: 'First, LOOK. What do you see? Has anything pushed through the soil? What color is it? How many leaves?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's look super carefully at our plant friends. Can you see if anything new has popped out of the dirt? Tell me what color it is and if you see any little leaves.

slides.text: 'Now MEASURE. Hold the ruler next to the stem. How tall is the plant? Write the number in your journal.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to measure! We'll take this special ruler and hold it right next to the plant's stem to see how tall it is. Then we'll write that number down in our special garden book.

slides.text: 'Draw what you see — the stem, the leaves, the soil. Try to draw it EXACTLY as it looks, not how you imagine it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to draw our plant just like it looks! We'll draw the tall stem, the little leaves, and the dirt. It's like making a picture of our plant for our special book.

slides.prompt: For each plant: observe, measure, draw, and write. Record: Date, Height, Number of leaves, Color, What you notice. Compare to your first drawing!
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to do everything we learned for each plant! We'll look, measure, and draw, and then write down all the important things like how tall it is and what it looks like. Then we'll look at our first drawing to see how much our plant has grown!

slides.text: 'You are keeping a real scientific journal! Every scientist records their observations. Your plants are growing because YOU took care of them.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child measure plant height, count leaves, and record accurate observations in their journal?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job being a scientist today! You looked so closely, measured so carefully, and drew such amazing pictures. Your plants are growing so big because you are such a good plant helper!

parent_notes: By now (two weeks after planting), bean seeds should have visible sprouts, making this observation lesson exciting. The child practices essential scientific skills: careful observation (what do you actually see, not what you expect to see), measurement (using a ruler), and documentation (recording data over time). Comparing today's drawing to the first journal entry shows growth over time — this is longitudinal data collection, a fundamental scientific practice. If some seeds didn't germinate, that's a learning opportunity too: 'Why do you think this one didn't grow? Was it too much water? Not enough light?' Hypothesis-making is science in action. Take a photo to supplement the journal.

title: Music — Dynamics: Loud, Soft, and Everything in Between
description: The child learns about musical dynamics — playing and singing at different volumes. They practice piano (soft), forte (loud), and crescendo (getting louder) with instruments and voice.
instructions:
1. 'Music can be LOUD or SOFT. Musicians call loudness DYNAMICS.'
2. Play a drum softly: 'This is called PIANO in music — it means soft.' Then loudly: 'This is FORTE — it means loud!'
3. 'Can you play your instrument softly? Now loudly? Feel the difference!'
4. Introduce CRESCENDO: 'Start very soft and get louder and louder and LOUDER!' Demonstrate on an instrument.
5. DIMINUENDO: 'Start loud and get softer and softer until it disappears!'
6. Play a familiar song with dynamics: verse soft, chorus loud.
7. 'When music gets louder, it feels exciting! When it gets softer, it feels mysterious or calm.'
8. Free play with dynamics.
materials_needed: Optional: recording of music with clear dynamics

slides.heading: Musical Dynamics
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the title for our music time today. We're going to learn about making music sound loud and soft, and all the fun sounds in between! It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Have instruments ready. If available, queue up a recording with clear dynamic changes (like Grieg's 'In the Hall of the Mountain King').
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool instruments! We have a drum for making big sounds, and a shaker or tambourine for smaller sounds. If you have music to listen to, that's great too! Let's get our instruments ready for our music adventure!

slides.text: 'Music isn't just about WHAT notes you play — it's about HOW you play them. DYNAMICS means how loud or soft the music is.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important! Music can be loud, or it can be soft. Think about a lion roaring – that's loud! Now think about a little mouse squeaking – that's soft! In music, we call how loud or soft we play "dynamics."

slides.text: 'PIANO means soft in music. Play your instrument softly.' Demonstrate. 'FORTE means loud. Play it loudly!' Demonstrate.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try some sounds! When the music word is "piano," it means play super soft, like a little whisper. *Whispers* Now, when the music word is "forte," it means play big and loud, like a happy shout! *Shouts* Can you try playing soft and then loud?

slides.text: 'Now the fun part: CRESCENDO means getting louder. Start very soft... a little louder... louder... LOUD!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really exciting one called "crescendo!" It means we start super soft, like we're tiptoeing, and then get louder and louder and LOUDER! Like when a train starts far away and gets closer and closer! Let's try making our instruments get louder and louder!

slides.text: 'DIMINUENDO is the opposite: start loud and get softer... softer... until it almost disappears.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like the opposite of crescendo, called "diminuendo." We start playing really loud, like a big boom, and then we get softer and softer and softer until it almost disappears, like a little whisper fading away. Let's practice getting softer and softer!

slides.prompt: Play your instrument with dynamics! When I say 'piano,' play softly. When I say 'forte,' play loudly. When I move my hand up, crescendo! Down, diminuendo!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to play! I'm going to say a word, and you play your instrument. When I say "piano," play soft. When I say "forte," play loud. Watch my hand – if it goes up, get louder (crescendo!), and if it goes down, get softer (diminuendo!). You can do it!

slides.text: 'Dynamics make music come alive! Without them, music would sound flat and boring. You now know four music words: piano, forte, crescendo, diminuendo!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child play soft and loud on command and demonstrate a crescendo and diminuendo?
slides.mascot_explanation: You were amazing! We learned that "piano" means soft and "forte" means loud. We also learned "crescendo" means getting louder and "diminuendo" means getting softer. Making music loud and soft makes it so exciting and fun, just like you did!

parent_notes: Dynamics are one of the most accessible musical concepts for young children because they relate to a universal experience: the difference between loud and soft. The Italian musical terms (piano, forte, crescendo, diminuendo) introduce the child to the international language of music. If you can play a recording of 'In the Hall of the Mountain King' by Grieg, it's a perfect example: the piece starts very soft and gradually builds to a thunderous climax. Children love this piece! You can also practice dynamics with the voice: whispering a song, singing normally, singing loudly. The key insight is that dynamics create emotion in music: soft passages feel intimate or mysterious, loud passages feel exciting or powerful.

title: Packing a Bag — Preparing for an Outing
description: The child learns to pack a bag for a trip or outing by thinking ahead about what they'll need. This develops planning, organization, and independence — essential executive function skills.
instructions:
1. 'When we go somewhere, we need to think AHEAD about what we'll need. Today we'll practice packing a bag!'
2. Scenario: 'We're going to the park for the afternoon. What will we need?'
3. Think together: 'What's the weather like? Do we need sunscreen? A jacket? Water?'
4. Make a list: water bottle, snack, sunscreen, hat, jacket (if cool), a book or toy, tissues.
5. 'Now gather each item and put it in the bag. Check off each item on the list.'
6. 'Is the bag packed neatly? Can you close it? Is it too heavy?'
7. Practice another scenario: packing for a sleepover, or a day at the beach.
8. 'Before any trip, think: WHERE am I going? WHAT will I need? Then pack!'
materials_needed: Items to pack (water bottle, snack, sunscreen, hat, etc.)
Paper and pencil for making a list

slides.heading: Packing a Bag
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is our special lesson about packing a bag! We're going to learn how to get ready for fun trips, just like a big kid!

items: Paper and pencil for the packing list
slides.setup_instructions: Gather potential items for packing. Have a backpack or tote bag available. Set up a flat surface for organizing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our packing adventure! We have a bag to put everything in, and lots of fun things we might want to take. We'll also need some paper and a pencil to help us remember what to pack.

slides.text: 'Grown-ups aren't the only ones who can pack a bag. YOU can do it! The secret is to THINK AHEAD about what you'll need.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? You can be a super packer too! The secret is to think about what you'll need *before* we go somewhere fun. It's like being a little planner!

slides.text: 'Let's say we're going to the park this afternoon. First, think about the weather. Is it hot? Cold? Rainy? What will you need for that weather?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, imagine we're going to the park! We need to think about the weather first. Is it sunny and hot, or maybe a little chilly? That helps us know if we need a hat or a jacket.

slides.text: 'Let's make a LIST. Water bottle? Check. Snack? Check. Sunscreen? Check. Hat? Check. Something to do? Check.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's make a special list of what to bring to the park! We'll put a check next to our water bottle, our yummy snack, sunscreen, a hat, and maybe a fun toy to play with.

slides.text: 'Now find each item and put it in the bag. Check off each one on your list. Pack it neatly so everything fits!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to pack! Let's find each thing on our list and put it carefully into the bag. After we put it in, we can put a little check mark on our list so we know we've packed it. Let's try to make it neat inside!

slides.prompt: Pack a bag for our park trip. Use the checklist. Then try a DIFFERENT scenario: pack for a sleepover! What different things would you need?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job packing for the park! Now, let's pretend we're going on a sleepover. What different things would we need to pack for that? Thinking ahead is so much fun!

slides.text: 'You can pack your own bag now! Before any trip, ask yourself: Where am I going? What will I need? Then make a list and pack.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a packing list appropriate for the scenario and pack a bag with all listed items?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a super packer now! Remember, before any trip, just ask yourself: "Where am I going?" and "What do I need?" Then you can make your list and pack your own bag all by yourself!

parent_notes: Packing a bag is an executive function powerhouse: the child must anticipate future needs, plan, organize, and execute. In Montessori, we want children to be as independent as possible, and packing their own bag is a real-world skill they can use immediately. Start with a familiar scenario (going to the park) and guide the thinking process. The checklist is a valuable tool — it teaches the child that lists help us remember things. Over time, the child should pack their own bag for outings, playdates, and eventually school. You might create a permanent checklist for common activities that the child can reference. The key question to teach: 'What will I need when I get there?'

title: Journal Writing — Drawing and Sentences
description: The child writes a journal entry with a drawing and 2-3 sentences about a personal experience or interest. This builds on the creative writing introduction and develops the habit of written self-expression.
instructions:
1. 'Authors write in journals to remember things that happen and how they feel. Today YOU will write a journal entry!'
2. 'Think about something that happened recently. Maybe our cooking project, your growing plants, or something fun you did.'
3. 'First, draw a picture about it at the top of the page.'
4. 'Now write 2 or 3 sentences below your picture. Tell me: What happened? How did you feel?'
5. Help with spelling only if asked. Encourage phonetic spelling: 'Write the sounds you hear.'
6. 'Write today's date at the top: that's how journals work — each entry has a date.'
7. Read the entry aloud together.
8. 'This journal is yours. You can add to it anytime!'
materials_needed: Journal or paper stapled into a booklet
Date written on a card for reference

slides.heading: Journal Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Journal Writing," and we're going to make our very own special book where we write and draw about things we do and how we feel. It's like a diary just for you!

slides.setup_instructions: If you don't have a journal, staple several pages together to make a simple booklet. Write today's date on a card.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our journal, we need a few things! We need a notebook or some paper to make a booklet, a pencil to write with, and some pretty colored pencils for drawing. We also have a little card with today's date so we know when we wrote in our special book. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these?

slides.text: 'A journal is a book where you write about YOUR life — YOUR experiences, YOUR thoughts, YOUR feelings. It's all about you!'
slides.mascot_explanation: A journal is like a special book that's all about YOU! It's a place where you can write down all the exciting things that happen in your life and how they make you feel. We get to fill it up with our own stories!

slides.text: 'Think about something that happened recently. Our cooking day? Your growing plants? Something fun or interesting? Pick ONE thing to write about.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about something super fun or interesting that happened to you recently. Maybe it was when we cooked together, or when you saw your plant grow bigger, or maybe something else you did! Pick just one thing to tell me about.

slides.text: 'First, draw a picture at the top of the page. Add details that help tell the story.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great choice! Now, at the very top of your page, let's draw a picture about that special thing you picked. Make it colorful and add lots of details so we can see all the fun parts of your story!

slides.text: 'Now write below your picture. Start with: Today I... or I made... or My favorite... Write 2 or 3 sentences. Sound out each word.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Below your amazing drawing, we're going to write some sentences. You can start with "Today I..." or "I made..." or "My favorite..." Try to write two or three sentences and sound out the words you hear!

slides.prompt: Write your journal entry: date, drawing, and 2-3 sentences. Read it back to yourself. Does it make sense? Would someone else understand it?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put it all together! We'll write today's date at the top, then our drawing, and then our two or three sentences. After we finish, we'll read it out loud together to make sure it tells our story perfectly.

slides.text: 'You wrote a journal entry! Over time, your journal will be full of YOUR stories. It's a treasure to keep and read again when you're older.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a dated journal entry with a drawing and at least 2 sentences about a personal experience?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You wrote your very own journal entry with a drawing and sentences, and it has the date on it too! This journal will be filled with all your wonderful stories, like a treasure box of memories for you to keep forever.

parent_notes: Journaling develops writing fluency — the more a child writes, the easier writing becomes. At this stage, the entries will be simple and the spelling phonetic. That is perfect. The goal is FLUENCY (writing easily and willingly), not ACCURACY (perfect spelling). If you correct every spelling error, the child learns to write less to avoid mistakes. Instead, celebrate what they wrote. 'You told me about making muffins! I can read every word!' Over time, reading exposure will improve spelling naturally. The dated entries create a wonderful record of the child's life and development. Years from now, these early journal entries will be priceless. Consider making journaling a daily habit, even if entries are brief.

title: Multiplication with Golden Beads — Introduction
description: The child uses golden beads for multiplication, building the same number multiple times and combining. This introduces multiplication with a familiar material and prepares for larger numbers.
instructions:
1. 'We've been doing multiplication with the stamp game. Today let's use the golden beads!'
2. Problem: 23 x 3. 'We need to build 23 three times.'
3. Three children (or three trays) each build 23: 2 ten bars and 3 units.
4. 'Now bring all the beads together! How many tens? 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 tens.'
5. 'How many units? 3 + 3 + 3 = 9 units.'
6. 'So 23 x 3 = 69!'
7. Try with exchange: 15 x 3. Units: 5 + 5 + 5 = 15 units. Exchange 10 for a ten bar.
8. '15 x 3 = 45. We had 3 tens + 15 units = 4 tens and 5 units = 45!'
materials_needed: Golden bead materials (units, ten bars, hundred squares)

slides.heading: Golden Bead Multiplication
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to learn about multiplication using our shiny golden beads. We've used these beads before, and now we get to do something super exciting with them!

items: Golden bead units and ten bars
slides.setup_instructions: Set out three trays for building the multiplicand. Have plenty of ten bars and units available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some special things for our math game today! We'll use these golden beads that look like tiny gold bars and little gold circles. We also need three flat trays to build on, some number cards, and a special mat to put everything on. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'You remember the golden beads from addition and subtraction? Today we use them for MULTIPLICATION!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we used the golden beads to count and put numbers together? Today, we're going to use them for something new called multiplication! It's like making groups of numbers really fast.

slides.text: '23 taken 3 times. Each tray gets 23: 2 ten bars and 3 units. Build the same number on all three trays!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's pretend we want to take the number 23 three times. We'll put the number 23 on each of our three trays. That means each tray gets two of those long ten bars and three little unit circles.

slides.text: 'Now combine! Push all the ten bars together: 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 ten bars. All the units: 3 + 3 + 3 = 9 units.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the magic part! Let's push all the beads from the three trays together onto our mat. How many long ten bars do we have all together? Let's count them: two, plus two, plus two makes six! And how many little circles? Three, plus three, plus three makes nine!

slides.text: '6 tens and 9 units = 69. So 23 x 3 = 69! Now try 15 x 3. But wait — 5 + 5 + 5 = 15 units! We need to exchange!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We have 6 tens and 9 units, which makes the number 69! So, 23 times 3 is 69! Now, let's try another one, 15 times 3. We'll have 15 little circles on each tray, and when we add them up, we get 15 circles! That's too many, so we need to trade 10 of them for a ten bar.

slides.prompt: Solve with golden beads: 12 x 4, 21 x 3, 14 x 3 (this one needs an exchange!). Build, combine, exchange if needed, and record each equation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some super math challenges! We're going to figure out 12 x 4, 21 x 3, and 14 x 3 using our golden beads. Remember to build the numbers, put them all together, and trade any groups of 10 for a new ten bar if you need to!

slides.text: 'Golden beads make multiplication visible! You can SEE how the quantities grow when you take a number many times.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build a two-digit number multiple times, combine, exchange when needed, and state the product?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job with multiplication today! You can see how the golden beads show us how numbers get bigger when we take them many times. You were so good at building, combining, and even doing those tricky exchanges!

parent_notes: Using golden beads for multiplication connects the child's earlier golden bead experience (addition, subtraction) to this newer operation. The process is the same as the stamp game but more concrete — the child handles real beads and feels the weight of increasing quantities. The three trays represent the three groups clearly. When exchange is needed (units exceed 9), the child applies the same exchange principle they learned in addition. This consistency across operations is a hallmark of Montessori math: the same materials and principles apply to all four operations. The child sees that multiplication is fundamentally repeated addition, just organized more efficiently.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Telephone Practice and Role Play
description: Role-playing various telephone scenarios including taking messages, calling for help, and making polite phone calls to family members.
instructions:
1. 'Telephones help us talk to people who aren't with us. Today we'll learn how to use the phone politely!'
2. Use play phones or real phones (not connected). Parent demonstrates:
3. ANSWERING: 'Hello, this is the [family name] home.' NOT just 'Hello?' or 'What?'
4. IF FOR YOU: 'Yes, this is [name]. How are you? ... That sounds nice! ... Thank you for calling. Goodbye!'
5. IF FOR SOMEONE ELSE: 'Let me get them for you. One moment, please.' Or: 'They can't come to the phone right now. Can I take a message?'
6. TAKING A MESSAGE: Write down: who called, their number, what they said.
7. Practice role-plays: child answers, parent calls with different scenarios.
8. 'Always be polite, speak clearly, and say goodbye before hanging up.'
materials_needed: Two play phones or old cell phones

slides.heading: Grace and Courtesy
slides.subheading: Grace and Courtesy — Telephone Practice and Role Play
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is about being super polite when we use the phone, like a grown-up. It's called "Grace and Courtesy," and we're going to practice talking on the phone so we can be very helpful friends.

items: Two play phones or old phones
slides.setup_instructions: Set up two 'phone stations' facing away from each other (to simulate not seeing the other person).
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at these fun things we need for our phone practice! We have two pretend phones so we can talk to each other, and some paper and a pencil to write down important messages, just like a real helper. Ask a grown-up to help you find these!

slides.text: 'When we're on the phone, the other person can't see us — they can only hear our VOICE. So we need to speak clearly and politely!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we talk on the phone, the other person can't see our smiling faces, can they? So, we need to use our best, clear voice to help them understand everything we say. Let's practice speaking super clearly!

slides.text: 'When the phone rings and you answer: Hello, this is the [your family name] home. How may I help you?' Practice this greeting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Ding, ding, ding! If the phone rings, we need to answer it super politely! We say, "Hello, this is the [family name] home. How may I help you?" That sounds so friendly and helpful, doesn't it?

slides.text: 'If the call is for you: Hello! ... If the call is for someone else: One moment please, let me get them.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, if it's a call just for you, you can say "Hello!" and talk all you want. But if it's for Mommy or Daddy, we say, "One moment please, let me get them," so we can go find them.

slides.text: 'If the person isn't available: They can't come to the phone right now. Can I take a message? Write down: who called and what they said.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, the person you want to talk to can't come to the phone right now. That's okay! We can say, "They can't come to the phone right now. Can I take a message?" and then we write down who called and what they said.

slides.prompt: Role-play! I'll call you with different scenarios. Practice: 1) A call for you, 2) A call for a parent, 3) Taking a message. Remember your polite words!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's time for our fun role-play! I'm going to pretend to call you, and you can practice answering the phone and taking messages, just like we learned. You're going to be so great at this!

slides.text: 'You know how to use the phone politely now! Good phone manners show respect for the person calling. Always speak clearly and say goodbye.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child answer the phone politely, handle a call for someone else, and take a basic message?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You are now a phone superstar and know how to talk so politely. You learned how to answer the phone, get someone else, and even take a message – that's amazing!

parent_notes: Grace and courtesy lessons are a distinctive feature of Montessori education. They teach children the social conventions that help them navigate the world with confidence. Telephone manners may seem old-fashioned, but the underlying skills — polite greeting, clear communication, message-taking, saying goodbye — apply to all forms of communication. Role-play is the best teaching method because the child practices in a safe context. Make it fun by being different callers: a grandparent, a friend, someone with a wrong number. The message-taking component integrates writing skills. As the child grows, these phone manners become real-life skills they use daily.

title: Read-Aloud: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day
description: Reading Judith Viorst's classic about a boy having the worst day ever. This humorous, relatable book validates children's frustrations and teaches that bad days happen to everyone.
instructions:
1. Show the cover: 'Have you ever had a really bad day? Alexander is about to have the WORST day ever!'
2. Read the story. Let the humor land: 'He went to sleep with gum in his hair. He woke up with gum in his hair.'
3. Each disaster: 'Oh no! Now what happened?' The child will laugh at the accumulating problems.
4. The repeated refrain: 'I think I'll move to Australia.' 'Why does he want to go to Australia? Does he think bad days don't happen there?'
5. The ending: 'His mom said some days are like that. Even in Australia.'
6. 'Has anything like this ever happened to you? What did you do?'
7. 'Everyone has bad days. The important thing is that tomorrow is a NEW day.'
materials_needed: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day by Judith Viorst

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this book, friend! It's called "Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day." That's a lot of words, huh? It means Alexander is going to have a super, super, super bad day!

items: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day
slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably. This book is best read with expression and humor.
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we get to read a special book together! For our reading adventure, we need this book, "Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day." We also need a super cozy spot to snuggle up in, maybe on the couch or with some pillows.

slides.text: 'The title of this book is VERY long: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day. That's a LOT of bad words. This day must be REALLY bad!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the title! It has so many words, and they all sound like sad, yucky feelings. It tells us this day is going to be really, really bad for Alexander, maybe the worst day ever!

slides.text: Read with expression. Each new disaster: emphasize and let the child react. They'll be laughing and sympathizing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story and make our voices sound excited when Alexander has problems! When something bad happens, we'll make a funny face or a silly sound, and you can laugh or say "Oh no!" with me!

slides.text: The repeated line: 'I think I'll move to Australia.' Ask: 'Why Australia? Do you think it would be better there?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alexander says he wants to move all the way to Australia! That's so far away! Let's think, do you think bad days happen in Australia too, or would it be better there?

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Tell me about YOUR worst day ever. What happened? How did you feel? What helped you feel better?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we read about Alexander's very bad day, tell me about a time YOU had a really yucky day. What happened that made it bad? And what did you do to feel better afterward?

slides.text: 'Some days are like that. Even in Australia. Bad days end, and tomorrow is brand new. What matters is how we handle them.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell at least 3 of Alexander's bad events and express the book's message that bad days happen to everyone?
slides.mascot_explanation: You know, sometimes days are just like that, even for people far, far away! But the best part is, after a bad day, a brand new day is always coming, full of new fun!

parent_notes: This book is powerful because it validates the child's experience of frustration and bad days. Children need to know that negative feelings are normal and that bad days are universal. Alexander's problems are relatable (gum in hair, no dessert in lunch, mean friends) and humorous in their accumulation. The mother's matter-of-fact response — 'some days are like that' — is important: she doesn't dismiss his feelings, but she also doesn't catastrophize. This models emotional regulation. You can use this book as a reference point when your child has a bad day: 'Sounds like an Alexander day! Remember, tomorrow is new.' The discussion about personal bad days builds emotional literacy and self-awareness.

title: Mystery Bag — Stereognostic Sense
description: The child identifies common objects placed in an opaque bag using only touch — no sight. This refines the stereognostic sense (the ability to recognize objects through touch alone) and builds descriptive vocabulary.
instructions:
1. Place 8-10 small, familiar objects in an opaque cloth bag: key, coin, pencil, button, shell, ball, spoon, block, paperclip, cotton ball.
2. 'In this bag are objects you know. But you can only use your HANDS to figure out what they are — no peeking!'
3. 'Reach in and touch ONE object. Don't pull it out yet! Describe what you feel: Is it smooth or rough? Hard or soft? Round or flat?'
4. 'Can you guess what it is?' Child guesses, then pulls it out to check.
5. Continue with each object. Increase difficulty by adding similar objects.
6. Variation: child describes the object and the PARENT guesses.
7. 'Your hands can tell you so much about the world, even without your eyes!'
materials_needed: 8-10 small familiar objects (key, coin, pencil, button, shell, ball, spoon, block, etc.)

slides.heading: Mystery Bag
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Mystery Bag," and that means we're going to play a super fun guessing game with our hands! We're going to try to figure out what things are without even looking at them.

slides.setup_instructions: Place all objects in the bag before the child sees them. Choose objects with distinct shapes and textures.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our game, we need a special bag that we can't see through, and some everyday things like a key or a button. We also need a mat to put our things on. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things so we can start playing?

slides.text: 'Your hands are AMAZING tools. Today we'll test how much your hands can tell you WITHOUT your eyes!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first secret instruction! It says our hands are like magic tools. We're going to see how much our hands can tell us about things, even when our eyes are closed or we can't see.

slides.text: 'Reach into the bag and touch ONE object. Don't take it out! Use your fingers to explore: What does it feel like?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time to play! Reach your hand inside the bag, but don't pull anything out yet. Just use your fingers to feel one thing really, really carefully.

slides.text: 'Tell me about it: Is it hard or soft? Smooth or bumpy? Big or small? Round or flat? Warm or cool?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, tell me all about what you feel! Is it super hard or soft like a pillow? Is it smooth like glass or bumpy like a toy car? Is it round like a ball or flat like a pancake?

slides.text: 'Based on what you feel, can you GUESS what it is? Say your guess, then pull it out to check!'
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a good job feeling it! Now, what do you think it is? Take a guess, and then pull it out to see if you were right! We'll do this for every surprise in the bag.

slides.prompt: Identify all the objects in the bag using only touch. Keep score: how many did you guess correctly? Then try putting objects IN the bag and describing them for ME to guess!
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to play the guessing game with all the things in the bag now! Let's see how many you can guess just by touching them. And guess what? We can even switch! You can put things in the bag and I'll try to guess what they are.

slides.text: 'Your stereognostic sense — your ability to know objects by touch — is incredible! Blind people use this sense to read Braille.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify at least 6 out of 8 objects by touch alone and describe their properties?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are so good at guessing what's in the bag with just your hands! It's like your fingers have special eyes. You learned how to know things without seeing them, which is super amazing, just like people who read special books with their fingers!

parent_notes: The mystery bag (or stereognostic bag) is one of Montessori's most engaging sensorial activities. The stereognostic sense — recognizing objects through touch — requires the brain to build a mental image from tactile information alone. This is a high-level cognitive process. The descriptive vocabulary (smooth, rough, hard, soft, round, flat, bumpy, pointed) is valuable language development. You can increase difficulty over time by using similar objects (different coins, different keys) that require finer discrimination. The reversal (child describes, parent guesses) develops communication skills — the child must choose descriptive words that convey the information clearly. This activity never gets old; just change the objects!

title: Continued Chapter Book Reading — Comprehension and Prediction
description: The child continues reading their chapter book from Day 2, practicing reading stamina and developing comprehension skills through prediction, summarizing, and character analysis.
instructions:
1. 'Let's continue our chapter book! Where did we leave off?' Child finds the bookmark.
2. Before reading: 'What happened in the last chapter? Can you predict what might happen next?'
3. Child reads Chapter 2 (or next chapter) aloud.
4. Pause occasionally: 'What do you think will happen next?' (prediction)
5. After reading: 'Summarize the chapter in 3 sentences. Beginning, middle, end.'
6. Character discussion: 'How does [character] feel? Why do you think they did that?'
7. 'What's your favorite part so far? What do you think will happen in the next chapter?'
8. Place the bookmark for next time.

slides.heading: Chapter Book Reading
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to read our chapter book again! We're going to be super readers and learn all about what happens in the story and guess what's coming next!

slides.setup_instructions: Find the bookmark from last time. Settle into the reading spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we need our special chapter book and the little ribbon we call a bookmark to know where we stopped. Let's find a cozy spot to sit, maybe with a grown-up, so we can read nicely.

slides.text: 'Welcome back to our chapter book! Before we read, let's remember: what happened in the last chapter?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Welcome back, friend! Before we open our book, let's think really hard. What happened the last time we read? Can you remember the story?

slides.text: 'What do you THINK will happen next? Make a PREDICTION — a guess based on what you know so far.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put on our thinking caps! What do you *guess* might happen in the story next? It's like a super fun guessing game based on what we already know!

slides.text: 'Now let's read the next chapter. Take your time. Use your phonics tools for new words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to read our next chapter! Take your time and read the words carefully, just like we practiced. If you see a word you don't know, try sounding it out, you can do it!

slides.text: After reading: 'Tell me what happened: the beginning, the middle, and the end of this chapter.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you read so well! Now, let's tell the story of this chapter. What happened first, then what happened in the middle, and what was the very last thing that happened?

slides.prompt: After reading, answer: 1) What happened? 2) How does the character feel? 3) Were your predictions right? 4) What will happen next? Optional: draw your favorite scene.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's talk about our story! How do you think the characters are feeling right now? Did anything happen that you guessed might happen? And what do you think will happen in the *next* chapter?

slides.text: 'You're a real reader now — making predictions, understanding characters, and reading chapter by chapter. Put the bookmark in for next time!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read with improved fluency compared to Day 2 and demonstrate comprehension through summary and prediction?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job reading and thinking about the story today! You're becoming such a smart reader, remembering what happened and guessing what's next. Let's put our bookmark in here so we know where to stop next time!

parent_notes: Comprehension strategies like predicting, summarizing, and analyzing characters are the heart of skilled reading. Teaching these explicitly helps the child become an active, thoughtful reader rather than a passive decoder. Prediction ('What do you think will happen?') engages the child's imagination and keeps them motivated to read on. Summarizing ('Tell me what happened') builds narrative understanding. Character analysis ('How does Frog feel? Why?') develops empathy and social reasoning. If the child reads the chapter with more fluency than on Day 2, point it out: 'You're reading more smoothly! The story is becoming easier because you know the characters and words now.'

title: Division Concept — Equal Sharing with Golden Beads
description: The child explores division concretely by sharing golden beads equally among groups. This 'sharing' model of division builds intuitive understanding before introducing any notation.
instructions:
1. 'Remember when we shared stamps? Today we'll share golden beads — bigger numbers!'
2. Problem: 'You have 36 beads. Share them equally among 3 friends.'
3. Build 36: 3 ten bars and 6 units.
4. 'Let's share the ten bars first. Give one to each friend: 1, 1, 1. Each gets 1 ten.'
5. 'Now the units: 6 units among 3 friends. Give one at a time: each gets 2 units.'
6. 'Each friend has 1 ten and 2 units = 12! So 36 shared among 3 is 12 each.'
7. Try: 48 ÷ 4. Build 48. Share ten bars (4 each get 1). Share units (8 among 4 = 2 each). Each gets 12.
8. 'Division means fair sharing!'
materials_needed: Golden bead materials (units and ten bars)
3-4 trays or bowls for sharing groups

slides.heading: Division with Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Division" and "Equal Sharing." That means we're going to learn how to share things so everyone gets the same amount, like when we share cookies!

items: Golden bead units and ten bars
slides.setup_instructions: Set out 3-4 trays in a row. Have plenty of golden beads available. The child will deal beads into the trays.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, these are the special things we need for our sharing game! We have shiny golden beads that look like little cubes, and longer sticks made of beads. We also need these trays to put the beads in, and a big mat to play on. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'Division means sharing EQUALLY — everyone gets the same amount. Today we'll share golden beads!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important for our game! It tells us that "division" is just a fancy word for sharing FAIRLY. We want to make sure everyone gets the exact same number of beads, just like sharing toys with friends.

slides.text: 'We have 36 beads. We need to share them among 3 friends.' Put out 3 trays. Build 36 (3 ten bars, 6 units).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here's our first sharing challenge! We have 36 golden beads, and we need to share them with 3 friends. Let's get our special trays ready, and then we'll build the number 36 with our beads.

slides.text: 'Start with the ten bars. Give one to each tray: 1... 1... 1. Each friend gets 1 ten. Good — the ten bars are shared!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's share the long bead sticks first! We have 3 of them, and we'll give one stick to each of the 3 trays. See? Each friend is starting with one long stick of beads!

slides.text: 'Now the units. 6 units among 3 friends. Deal one at a time: 1-1-1, 2-2-2. Each gets 2! So each friend has 12.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job sharing the sticks! Now let's share the little single beads. We have 6 little beads and 3 friends. We'll give one little bead to each tray, then another, until they are all gone. Look, each friend got 2 little beads!

slides.text: '36 shared among 3 = 12 each. That's DIVISION! Let's write it: 36 ÷ 3 = 12. The ÷ sign means divided by.'
